questions.text: Providing comprehensive background information on a topic demonstrates thorough understanding.
questions.explanation: Only answer what's asked. Describing all stages of the business cycle when asked to identify ONE stage wastes time and earns no extra marks.
questions.studyTip: Read the question. Answer THAT question. Nothing more.

questions.text: Inclusion of material beyond the scope of the question will not add value to your response.
questions.explanation: Extra detail on RBA operations or transmission mechanisms when not asked wastes valuable time. Use that time on other questions instead.
questions.studyTip: Stay focused. Extra content = wasted time, not extra marks.

questions.text: If you explain the main concept well, minor requirements like 'reference to the chart' are optional.
questions.explanation: Explicit requirements must be addressed. 'Reference to the chart' means cite specific data. 'Fully labelled diagram' means all labels required. Missing these loses marks.
questions.studyTip: Highlight EVERY requirement. Tick them off as you address each one.

questions.text: When a question requires 'reference to' data or a chart, you must explicitly cite that information.
questions.explanation: Many students lost marks by not referencing charts despite explicit requirements. If the question says 'reference to', you must do it.
questions.studyTip: 'Reference to' = you MUST cite it. Not optional.

questions.text: A 2-mark question about exchange rate movement requires full equilibrium adjustment analysis.
questions.explanation: Mark allocation indicates depth required. A 2-mark question needs a concise response. Save detailed analysis for higher-mark questions.
questions.studyTip: 2 marks = brief. 6 marks = detailed. Match depth to marks.

questions.text: The task word and marks allocated indicate how much detail is required in your response.
questions.explanation: A question asking for 'impact on a market' (2 marks) doesn't need full disequilibrium analysis. Higher-mark questions will explicitly request more detail.
questions.studyTip: Check marks first. Plan response length accordingly.

questions.text: Using arrows and economic symbols (↑AD → ↑P) is an efficient way to communicate economic relationships.
questions.explanation: Shorthand with arrows cannot convey the complexity of economic relationships. Full sentences are required to demonstrate understanding and earn full marks.
questions.studyTip: No arrows. No symbols. Write in complete sentences.

questions.text: Responses must be written in full sentences and paragraphs to earn full marks.
questions.explanation: Economic relationships are complex. 'AD increases → inflation increases' doesn't explain WHY. Full sentences show you understand the mechanism.
questions.studyTip: Full sentences show understanding. Symbols show shortcuts.

questions.text: Defining the macroeconomic goal in every part of a multi-part question shows thorough knowledge.
questions.explanation: If you define a goal in part c., you don't need to define it again in part d. Unnecessary definitions waste time without earning marks.
questions.studyTip: Define once. Don't repeat in subsequent parts of the same question.

questions.text: Once a goal is defined in one part of a question, repeating the definition in later parts is unnecessary.
questions.explanation: Assessors read all parts together. Repeating definitions signals you're padding rather than demonstrating deeper understanding.
questions.studyTip: First mention = define if needed. After that = just apply.

concepts.title: Know key definitions from Study Design

questions.text: You can explain concepts in your own words rather than memorising formal definitions.
questions.explanation: Many students showed tenuous grasp of key terms. Study Design definitions must be committed to memory—vague explanations lose marks.
questions.studyTip: Memorise Study Design definitions. Vague ≠ correct.

questions.text: Key economic definitions from the Study Design must be committed to memory.
questions.explanation: Questions test specific terminology. If you can't accurately define 'full employment' or 'price stability', you can't apply them correctly.
questions.studyTip: Make flashcards for every Study Design term. Test yourself.

questions.text: A 'leftward movement along the demand curve' means the demand curve shifts to the left.
questions.explanation: Movement ALONG = price change causes quantity demanded to change. SHIFT OF = non-price factor changes the whole curve's position. This distinction is critical.
questions.studyTip: Price → movement along. Non-price factor → shift.

questions.text: Price factors cause movements along curves, while non-price factors cause shifts of curves.
questions.explanation: Many students confused these. A contraction along the demand curve (less quantity demanded) follows from higher prices, not a shift of the curve.
questions.studyTip: Movement = along existing curve. Shift = new curve position.

questions.text: For a microeconomic demand and supply diagram, you can label axes as 'Price Level' and 'Real GDP'.
questions.explanation: Price Level and Real GDP are for AD/AS diagrams. Micro diagrams need 'Price' (y-axis) and 'Quantity' (x-axis). Mixing these shows conceptual confusion.
questions.studyTip: Micro: Price vs Quantity. Macro: Price Level vs Real GDP.

questions.text: Demand and supply diagrams require 'Price' on the y-axis and 'Quantity' on the x-axis.
questions.explanation: Common errors include confusing axes or using AD/AS labels. Always Price (vertical), Quantity (horizontal) for micro diagrams.
questions.studyTip: P on y-axis, Q on x-axis. Every time. No exceptions.

questions.text: It doesn't matter which direction your demand and supply curves slope as long as they cross.
questions.explanation: Demand curves slope downward (inverse price-quantity relationship). Supply curves slope upward (direct relationship). Wrong slopes = fundamental error.
questions.studyTip: Demand: downward. Supply: upward. Basic but essential.

questions.text: Demand curves must slope downward and supply curves must slope upward.
questions.explanation: Some students drew upward-sloping demand curves. This is a fundamental error that undermines the entire analysis.
questions.studyTip: Check your slopes before moving on. Wrong slope = zero marks.

questions.text: A 'fully labelled' diagram just needs the axes labelled correctly.
questions.explanation: 'Fully labelled' requires: axes labels, curve labels (D1, S1, S2), equilibrium points (E1, E2), price levels (P1, P2), quantities (Q1, Q2).
questions.studyTip: Fully labelled = axes + curves + equilibria + P + Q. All of them.

questions.text: A fully labelled demand and supply diagram includes axes, curves, equilibrium points, prices, and quantities.
questions.explanation: Missing any element loses marks. Label everything clearly. Take the extra 30 seconds to ensure completeness.
questions.studyTip: Checklist: Axes? Curves? Shift? Old E? New E? P1→P2? Q1→Q2?

concepts.title: Don't draw AD/AS for micro questions

questions.text: Drawing AD and AS curves for a question about the housing market shows macroeconomic understanding.
questions.explanation: Housing market = micro demand and supply, not AD/AS. Using macro curves for micro questions shows confusion between analytical frameworks.
questions.studyTip: Specific market (housing, labour) = micro D&S. Whole economy = AD/AS.

questions.text: Questions about specific markets like housing or labour require micro demand and supply diagrams, not AD/AS.
questions.explanation: AD/AS is for aggregate economy analysis. Individual markets need standard demand and supply curves. Match the framework to the question.
questions.studyTip: Read carefully: Is it about ONE market or the WHOLE economy?

questions.text: An increase in equilibrium 'quantity traded' and an increase in 'quantity supplied' mean the same thing.
questions.explanation: Quantity supplied implies movement along the supply curve. Quantity traded is the equilibrium outcome. Using wrong terminology shows misunderstanding.
questions.studyTip: Quantity traded = equilibrium. Quantity supplied = point on supply curve.

questions.text: You must use correct language: 'quantity traded' at equilibrium differs from 'quantity supplied' on the curve.
questions.explanation: Precision matters. Equilibrium quantity traded results from the intersection. Quantity supplied is one side of that equation.
questions.studyTip: Be precise. The terms aren't interchangeable.

questions.text: Explaining that higher interest rates reduce confidence and therefore consumption demonstrates transmission mechanism understanding.
questions.explanation: Consumer confidence is NOT a transmission mechanism. The four channels are: savings/investment, cash-flow, exchange rate, and asset prices/wealth.
questions.studyTip: Four channels only. Confidence isn't one of them.

questions.text: The four monetary policy transmission mechanisms are: savings/investment, cash-flow, exchange rate, and asset prices/wealth.
questions.explanation: Know each channel and how it works. If asked about one specific channel, explain THAT channel—don't describe a different one.
questions.studyTip: Name your channel, then explain its specific mechanism.

questions.text: The asset prices/wealth channel works because higher interest rates reduce demand for houses, lowering prices and inflation.
questions.explanation: This skips the mechanism. Lower house prices reduce the 'paper wealth' of asset owners → negative wealth effect → reduced willingness to spend → lower consumption → lower AD.
questions.studyTip: Full chain: Prices → wealth → spending behaviour → AD.

questions.text: The asset prices/wealth channel operates through changes in perceived wealth affecting consumption spending.
questions.explanation: When asset values fall, owners feel poorer and reduce spending even if income unchanged. This 'wealth effect' dampens consumption and AD.
questions.studyTip: Wealth effect: Feel richer → spend more. Feel poorer → spend less.

questions.text: Explaining monetary policy stance theoretically (what the RBA 'could' do) is sufficient for contemporary questions.
questions.explanation: Contemporary questions require current evidence: actual cash rate, recent budget figures, current unemployment and inflation rates. Theoretical responses earn fewer marks.
questions.studyTip: Know current data: cash rate, budget balance, unemployment, inflation.

questions.text: Questions about current policy stance require reference to actual contemporary data like the cash rate and budget figures.
questions.explanation: High-scoring responses cited specific figures: cash rate at 4.35%, 2024-25 budget deficit of $28.3 billion. Generic responses without data score poorly.
questions.studyTip: Memorise key current figures before the exam. Update them regularly.

questions.text: Budgetary policy has a short implementation lag because the government can change it quickly.
questions.explanation: Discretionary budgetary policy has LONG implementation lags due to parliamentary negotiations. Only AUTOMATIC stabilisers operate quickly and contemporaneously.
questions.studyTip: Automatic = quick (contemporaneous). Discretionary = slow (parliament).

questions.text: Automatic stabilisers operate contemporaneously, while discretionary changes require parliamentary approval.
questions.explanation: If arguing budgetary policy can act quickly, you MUST reference automatic stabilisers or the cyclical component. Discretionary policy is slow.
questions.studyTip: Quick fiscal response? Must be automatic stabilisers.

questions.text: Describing the movement in budget outcome (deficit to surplus) fully explains budgetary policy stance.
questions.explanation: You must link the stance to current economic conditions. HOW did low unemployment and high inflation influence the stance? Not just what the stance is.
questions.studyTip: Conditions → Policy response. Show the causal link.

questions.text: High-scoring responses link economic conditions (unemployment, inflation rates) to the choice of policy stance.
questions.explanation: Why is policy contractionary? Because unemployment is below NAIRU and inflation is above target. Connect conditions to policy decisions.
questions.studyTip: Low unemployment + high inflation → contractionary. Explain WHY.

questions.text: Generic strengths of monetary policy (like flexibility) earn full marks for any question about strengths.
questions.explanation: Strengths must be relevant to the past 2 years. Explain HOW the strength helped achieve goals in the current context, not just what the strength is.
questions.studyTip: Strength + how it helped recently. Not just textbook strengths.

questions.text: Questions about policy strengths require explaining how those strengths have operated in the contemporary context.
questions.explanation: RBA's independence allowed unpopular rate rises before the 2022 election. Stage 3 tax cuts targeted household spending. Link strengths to recent events.
questions.studyTip: Generic strength → contemporary example → how it helped achieve goals.

questions.text: Explaining how AS policies increase supply and lower prices fully addresses 'complementary' role questions.
questions.explanation: 'Complementary' means AS policies work WITH AD policies. The key insight: AS expansion allows AD stimulus without inflation. You must mention BOTH.
questions.studyTip: Complementary = AD can expand BECAUSE AS has expanded. Both needed.

questions.text: AS and AD policies are complementary because AS expansion allows AD stimulus without triggering inflation.
questions.explanation: AS policies increase productive capacity. This allows AD policies to stimulate spending without hitting capacity constraints that cause inflation. That's 'complementary'.
questions.studyTip: AS expands capacity → AD can grow → no inflation. That's the link.

concepts.title: Interest rates are AD not AS

questions.text: Higher interest rates can be considered an AS factor because they increase production costs for businesses.
questions.explanation: Interest rates are an AD policy tool. The RBA uses them to influence AD, not AS. Don't confuse cost impacts with policy classification.
questions.studyTip: Interest rates = AD policy. Full stop.

questions.text: Monetary policy (interest rates) is an AD policy, not an AS policy, regardless of any cost impacts.
questions.explanation: Some students argued RBA rate rises cause inflation via costs. This misunderstands monetary policy's purpose: restraining AD to reduce demand inflation.
questions.studyTip: Monetary policy → AD manipulation. Even if costs rise, it's still AD policy.

questions.text: Stating that 'increased productivity leads to increased AS and achievement of the goal' is a complete explanation.
questions.explanation: You must explain WHY. Productivity increases → more output per input → lower per-unit costs → greater willingness to supply → AS increases → downward price pressure → AD stimulated.
questions.studyTip: Show the full chain: Why does productivity increase AS? How?

questions.text: AS explanations must show the causal chain from the policy to productivity to costs to AS to goal achievement.
questions.explanation: High-scoring responses explain mechanisms fully. Skilled migration → fills shortages → higher labour productivity → lower unit costs → increased AS.
questions.studyTip: Policy → AS factor improved → how this increases AS → goal impact.

concepts.title: Don't confuse business confidence with AS

questions.text: Business confidence is an important AS factor that influences productive capacity.
questions.explanation: Business confidence is an AD factor—it drives investment expenditure, which is a component of AD. Don't confuse AD drivers with AS factors.
questions.studyTip: Business confidence → investment → AD. Not an AS factor.

questions.text: Business confidence influences investment expenditure, making it an AD factor rather than an AS factor.
questions.explanation: AS factors: labour productivity, participation, technology, natural resources. Business confidence affects spending decisions, not productive capacity directly.
questions.studyTip: Know your AS factors: productivity, participation, resources, technology.

questions.text: Headline inflation and underlying budget balance are related concepts that can be discussed together.
questions.explanation: These are completely different concepts. Headline vs underlying INFLATION refers to CPI vs trimmed mean. Headline vs underlying BUDGET is cyclical vs structural. Don't confuse them.
questions.studyTip: Inflation: headline (CPI) vs underlying (trimmed mean). Budget: cyclical vs structural.

questions.text: Underlying inflation removes volatile price changes, while headline inflation includes all price movements.
questions.explanation: RBA's trimmed mean removes top and bottom 15% of price changes. Volatile items (petrol, fruit/veg) affect headline but not underlying. Know the difference.
questions.studyTip: Underlying = volatility removed. More stable, better for policy.

questions.text: Full employment means zero unemployment in the economy.
questions.explanation: Full employment is the NAIRU: lowest unemployment rate without accelerating inflation. Includes frictional and structural unemployment but no cyclical unemployment. Target: ~4-4.5%.
questions.studyTip: Full employment ≠ zero unemployment. It's NAIRU: 4-4.5%.

questions.text: Full employment (NAIRU) is achieved when there is no cyclical unemployment and inflation remains stable.
questions.explanation: At NAIRU, the labour market is in balance. Below NAIRU creates inflationary pressure from tight labour markets. Above means cyclical unemployment exists.
questions.studyTip: Below NAIRU = overfull employment = wage pressure = inflation risk.

questions.text: Evaluating goal achievement means explaining whether the goal has been met.
questions.explanation: Evaluation requires balanced assessment: benchmarks, current performance, points FOR and AGAINST achievement. Not just a yes/no judgment.
questions.studyTip: Evaluate = benchmark + evidence + for + against + judgment.

questions.text: Evaluating goal achievement requires considering benchmarks, current data, and arguments both for and against success.
questions.explanation: For inflation: target is 2-3%. Current headline is 2.8% but underlying is 3.5%. For: headline in range. Against: underlying above, temporary factors. Weigh both.
questions.studyTip: Always present both sides when evaluating. Then make your judgment.

questions.text: If growth is too low, it leads to decreased international competitiveness.
questions.explanation: Causality is reversed. Low competitiveness may CAUSE low growth, not the other way around. Low growth actually reduces inflation, which IMPROVES competitiveness.
questions.studyTip: Get causality right. What causes what? Don't reverse the chain.

questions.text: Strong and sustainable growth means the highest rate possible before inflation, environmental, or external pressures emerge.
questions.explanation: Target: 3-3.5% real GDP growth. Too low: unemployment rises. Too high: inflation accelerates, environment degrades. Balance is key.
questions.studyTip: Too low = unemployment. Too high = inflation, environmental pressure.

questions.text: A depreciation of the AUD reduces the value of net exports because imports become more expensive.
questions.explanation: Depreciation INCREASES net exports: exports cheaper in foreign currency (more competitive), imports more expensive (substitution to domestic). Net export value rises.
questions.studyTip: Depreciation → exports cheaper → imports dearer → net exports UP.

questions.text: Exchange rate depreciation improves competitiveness of exports and increases net export demand.
questions.explanation: Lower AUD = foreigners have more purchasing power in Australia = more export demand. Australians find imports expensive = buy domestic instead.
questions.studyTip: Depreciation helps exporters, hurts importers. Net effect: higher NX.

concepts.title: Terms of trade vs exchange rate

questions.text: A higher Terms of Trade contributes to exchange rate depreciation.
questions.explanation: Higher TOT (export prices rising relative to import prices) typically causes APPRECIATION, not depreciation. More demand for AUD to buy our expensive exports.
questions.studyTip: Higher TOT → appreciation. Lower TOT → depreciation.

questions.text: Higher Terms of Trade typically leads to exchange rate appreciation, while lower TOT leads to depreciation.
questions.explanation: Many students got this backwards. Higher export prices increase foreign demand for AUD to purchase Australian goods, appreciating the currency.
questions.studyTip: TOT up → AUD demand up → appreciation. Know this relationship.

questions.text: Lower relative interest rates in Australia lead to capital inflow and currency appreciation.
questions.explanation: Lower RELATIVE rates = capital OUTFLOW (investors seek higher returns elsewhere) = increased supply of AUD = depreciation. Many students reversed this.
questions.studyTip: Lower relative rates → capital outflow → depreciation.

questions.text: When Australia's interest rates are lower relative to other countries, capital outflows increase, depreciating the AUD.
questions.explanation: Investors chase higher returns. If US rates rise faster than Australian rates, money flows out of Australia, increasing AUD supply in forex markets.
questions.studyTip: Money follows higher returns. Lower relative rates = money leaves.

concepts.title: Structural vs cyclical current account factors

questions.text: Strong domestic demand increasing import spending is a structural factor affecting the current account.
questions.explanation: Demand fluctuations are CYCLICAL factors. Structural factors: chronic savings-investment imbalance, relative cost structures, productivity differences.
questions.studyTip: Structural = persistent/underlying. Cyclical = fluctuating with economy.

questions.text: Structural current account factors include chronic savings-investment imbalances and relative cost competitiveness.
questions.explanation: Australia's persistent CAD reflects structural issues: we invest more than we save (borrowing required), and high wages affect competitiveness. These don't change with the business cycle.
questions.studyTip: Structural factors persist across cycles. They're built into the economy.

questions.text: Foreign investment in Australia is recorded in the current account.
questions.explanation: Foreign investment is recorded in the CAPITAL AND FINANCIAL account. The current account records trade in goods/services and income flows.
questions.studyTip: Current account = trade + income. Capital/financial = investment flows.

questions.text: The current account records trade in goods and services, while investment flows appear in the capital and financial account.
questions.explanation: Many students confuse which account records what. BOGS (trade) and primary income (investment returns) are current account. Actual investment transactions are capital/financial.
questions.studyTip: Where money goes: Current = goods/services/income. Capital = investments.

questions.text: Writing 'An increase in AD leads to an increase in inflation' demonstrates economic understanding.
questions.explanation: This is an assertion, not an explanation. WHY does AD increase inflation? Pressure on capacity → shortages → price pressures → inflation accelerates.
questions.studyTip: Add the mechanism: AD up → capacity pressure → shortages → prices up.

questions.text: Economic explanations must include the mechanism linking cause to effect, not just state the relationship.
questions.explanation: Assertions without mechanisms earn few marks. Show you understand WHY the relationship exists, not just that it exists.
questions.studyTip: Every economic claim needs a 'because'. Add the reasoning.

questions.text: A decrease in costs of production increases productivity.
questions.explanation: Causality reversed. Productivity CAUSES lower costs, not the other way. More output per input → lower per-unit costs. Don't confuse cause and effect.
questions.studyTip: Productivity up → costs per unit down. Not: costs down → productivity up.

questions.text: Higher productivity allows more output from the same inputs, reducing per-unit costs and increasing AS.
questions.explanation: Productivity = output per unit of input. If you produce more from same inputs, cost per item falls. This increases willingness to supply.
questions.studyTip: More output per input → lower unit cost → more willing to supply.

questions.text: An increase in AS directly increases production and real GDP.
questions.explanation: Incomplete. AS increase puts downward pressure on prices, which STIMULATES AD for the increased output. The demand response completes the growth picture.
questions.studyTip: AS up → prices down → AD stimulated → growth. Include the demand response.

questions.text: An increase in AS puts downward pressure on prices, which stimulates AD and allows non-inflationary growth.
questions.explanation: AS alone doesn't cause growth—you need demand for the extra output. Lower prices from AS expansion stimulate that demand.
questions.studyTip: Supply creates conditions. Demand must follow. Both needed for growth.

questions.text: Opportunity cost is the price or cost of the next-best alternative.
questions.explanation: Opportunity cost is the BENEFIT or VALUE forgone, not the price. What you give up in terms of satisfaction or value, not what you pay.
questions.studyTip: Opportunity cost = benefit forgone, NOT price paid.

questions.text: Opportunity cost is the value of the next-best alternative forgone when making an economic decision.
questions.explanation: Land used for wheat has opportunity cost of the VALUE of rice production forgone (if that's next-best alternative). Focus on value given up.
questions.studyTip: What VALUE did you sacrifice? That's opportunity cost.

questions.text: Explaining impact on one macroeconomic goal automatically covers living standards impact.
questions.explanation: Living standards must be addressed separately. Growth → higher incomes → more goods/services → improved material living standards. Don't assume it's implied.
questions.studyTip: If question asks about living standards, address them explicitly.

questions.text: Questions asking about macroeconomic goals AND living standards require explicit discussion of both.
questions.explanation: Many students linked depreciation to full employment but didn't extend to living standards. Higher employment → higher incomes → better material LS. Say it.
questions.studyTip: Goal achieved → flow-on to living standards. Make the link explicit.

questions.text: A budget deficit directly increases net foreign debt.
questions.explanation: Budget deficit increases NET GOVERNMENT (public) debt, not net foreign debt. These are different concepts. Public debt is domestically and foreign held; net foreign debt is broader.
questions.studyTip: Budget deficit → public debt up. Not the same as foreign debt.

questions.text: A budget deficit means the government must borrow, increasing the level of public debt.
questions.explanation: Deficit = spending exceeds revenue = shortfall funded by borrowing = debt increases. Surplus = excess can repay debt. Know this relationship.
questions.studyTip: Deficit = borrow more. Surplus = repay debt. Simple relationship.

concepts.title: Deficits can't be financed by raising taxes

questions.text: Budget deficits can be financed by raising taxes.
questions.explanation: If you raise taxes enough to cover the shortfall, you no longer have a deficit. Deficits are financed by BORROWING (selling bonds), not by tax increases.
questions.studyTip: Deficit exists BECAUSE revenue is insufficient. Finance = borrowing.

questions.text: Budget deficits are financed by borrowing, typically through selling government bonds.
questions.explanation: Government can sell bonds to domestic investors (least expansionary due to crowding out), foreign investors, or the central bank. That's how deficits are funded.
questions.studyTip: Deficit funding options: domestic bonds, foreign bonds, central bank.

questions.text: The budget moving into surplus automatically indicates a contractionary policy stance.
questions.explanation: The CYCLICAL component moves automatically with the economy. A surplus might reflect automatic stabilisers in a boom, not deliberate policy. Consider structural component too.
questions.studyTip: Cyclical = automatic. Structural = deliberate. Both affect the balance.

questions.text: Analysing policy stance requires distinguishing between cyclical (automatic) and structural (discretionary) budget components.
questions.explanation: High inflation + low unemployment automatically boost revenue and cut welfare spending (cyclical). This is different from deliberate policy choices (structural).
questions.studyTip: Boom → cyclical improvement (automatic). Deliberate cuts → structural.

questions.text: Referring to theoretical budgetary policy responses is sufficient for contemporary questions.
questions.explanation: Questions about '2024-25 budget' require specific knowledge. Many students incorrectly referred to the wrong budget year. Know recent figures.
questions.studyTip: Know: Which budget year? Surplus or deficit? Key measures?

questions.text: Contemporary budget questions require knowledge of specific recent budget figures and measures.
questions.explanation: The 2024-25 budget is in deficit of $28.3 billion (expansionary) due to low growth. Stage 3 tax cuts aim to stimulate consumption. Know the specifics.
questions.studyTip: Update your budget knowledge yearly. Know stance, balance, key measures.

questions.text: The unemployment rate and underutilisation rate are calculated the same way.
questions.explanation: Unemployment rate = unemployed ÷ labour force. Underutilisation rate adds underemployed. Know both calculations and the difference.
questions.studyTip: Underutilisation = unemployed + underemployed. Broader measure.

questions.text: Labour force underutilisation includes both unemployment and underemployment as a proportion of the labour force.
questions.explanation: This question was poorly handled in 2023. Underutilisation captures more labour market slack than unemployment alone.
questions.studyTip: Underutilisation = unemployment rate + underemployment rate.

questions.text: High inflation delays consumption as consumers wait for prices to fall.
questions.explanation: High inflation ACCELERATES consumption—people buy now before prices rise further. Deflation delays consumption. Know the difference.
questions.studyTip: High inflation → buy now. Deflation → wait for lower prices.

questions.text: High inflation erodes purchasing power and reduces international competitiveness.
questions.explanation: 7.8% inflation: money buys less (purchasing power down), Australian goods more expensive overseas (competitiveness down). These are key consequences.
questions.studyTip: Inflation consequences: purchasing power, competitiveness, investment distortion.

questions.text: Transfer payments like JobSeeker are counted as government consumption expenditure.
questions.explanation: Transfer payments are NOT government expenditure on goods/services. They're redistributions. Current expenditure (wages, services), capital expenditure (infrastructure), and transfers are different.
questions.studyTip: Transfers ≠ G. They're redistributions, not purchases.

questions.text: Government expenditure categories include current expenditure, capital expenditure, and transfer payments (which are distinct).
questions.explanation: Current: wages, services. Capital: infrastructure. Transfers: welfare payments. Know the differences for multiple choice questions.
questions.studyTip: G in AD = current + capital. Transfers are separate (affect C instead).

questions.text: Relative prices measure the general price level in the economy.
questions.explanation: Relative prices compare ONE good's price to another's. General price level is measured by CPI. Many students confused these in 2024.
questions.studyTip: Relative price = price of A compared to price of B. Not general inflation.

questions.text: Relative prices indicate how much of one good must be given up to obtain another good.
questions.explanation: If beef price rises faster than chicken price, beef's relative price has increased. You give up more chicken to get the same beef.
questions.studyTip: Relative price = opportunity cost in exchange. How much B for one A?
